sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Hospitalize patients for the first 9 days of the first cycle and the first 2 days of the second cycle; provide healthcare professional supervision or hospitalization for the start of all subsequent cycles or for reinitiation of treatment (eg, after interruption of 4 or more hours)
  • Philadelphia chromosome-negative B-cell precursor acute lymphoblastic leukemia, Relapsed or refractory: Cycle 1 (weight 45 kg or greater): 9 mcg/day continuous IV infusion on days 1 through 7 and 28 mcg/day continuous IV infusion on days 8 through 28; 4 weeks continuous IV infusion followed by at least 2 weeks of no treatment; premedicate with dexamethasone 20 mg IV 1 hour before the first blinatumomab dose of each cycle, before a step dose (eg, cycle 1 day 8), or when restarting an infusion after an interruption of 4 or more hours
  • Philadelphia chromosome-negative B-cell precursor acute lymphoblastic leukemia, Relapsed or refractory: Subsequent cycles (weight 45 kg or greater): 28 mcg/day continuous IV infusion on days 1 through 28 followed by at least 2 weeks of no treatment; premedicate with dexamethasone 20 mg IV 1 hour before the first blinatumomab dose of each cycle, before a step dose (eg, cycle 1 day 8), or when restarting an infusion after an interruption of 4 or more hours; up to 2 cycles for induction followed by 3 additional cycles for consolidation (up to a total of 5 cycles)

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• Cytokine release syndrome, grade 3: Withhold treatment until resolved; restart at 9 mcg/day for 7 days, then increase to 28 mcg/day if toxicity has not recurred; if treatment interruption is 7 days or less, continue the same cycle to a total of 28 days, including the days before and after the interruption; if treatment interruption is longer than 7 days, start a new cycle
  • Cytokine release syndrome, grade 4: Permanently discontinue treatment
  • Neurotoxicity, grade 3: Withhold treatment until grade 1 or less for at least 3 days; restart at 9 mcg/day for 7 days, then increase to 28 mcg/day if toxicity has not recurred; if toxicity occurred at 9 mcg/day or does not resolve in 7 days or less, permanently discontinue treatment; if treatment interruption is 7 days or less, continue the same cycle to a total of 28 days, including the days before and after the interruption; if treatment interruption is longer than 7 days, start a new cycle
  • Neurotoxicity, grade 4: Permanently discontinue treatment
  • Seizure: Permanently discontinue treatment if more than 1 seizure occurs
  • Adverse reaction, clinically relevant grade 3: Withhold treatment until grade 1 or less; restart at 9 mcg/day for 7 days, then increase to 28 mcg/day if adverse reaction has not recurred; if not resolved in 14 days or less, permanently discontinue treatment; if treatment interruption is 7 days or less, continue the same cycle to a total of 28 days, including the days before and after the interruption; if treatment interruption is longer than 7 days, start a new cycle
  • Adverse reaction, clinically relevant grade 4: Consider permanent discontinuation

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Philadelphia chromosome-negative B-cell precursor acute lymphoblastic leukemia, Relapsed or refractory

2.title: Black Box Warning
2.mono:
Intravenous (Powder for Solution)
Cytokine release syndrome has been reported, and may be life-threatening or fatal. Severe, life-threatening, and fatal neurological toxicities have also occurred. Blinatumomab should be interrupted or discontinued as recommended.

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: Hypersensitivity to blinatumomab or to any component of the formulation

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Black Box Warning:
  • -- Cytokine release syndrome, possibly life-threatening or fatal, has been reported; monitoring recommended and interruption or discontinuation may be necessary
  • -- Neurological toxicities, sometimes severe, life-threatening, or fatal, have been commonly reported; monitoring recommended and interruption or discontinuation may be necessary
  • Hematologic:
  • -- Neutropenia and febrile neutropenia, sometimes life-threatening, have been reported; monitoring recommended and interrupt therapy if prolonged neutropenia occurs
  • Hepatic:
  • -- Transient elevations in liver enzymes, including grade 3 or higher, have been reported with and without comorbid cytokine release syndrome (CRS); monitoring recommended and interruption may be necessary
  • Immunologic:
  • -- Serious infections including sepsis, pneumonia, bacteremia, opportunistic infections, and catheter-site infections have been commonly reported; prophylactic use of appropriate antibiotics and monitoring recommended
  • Neurologic:
  • -- Loss of consciousness may occur due to the potential for neurologic events including seizures; driving during blinatumomab therapy not recommended
  • -- Cranial MRI changes showing leukoencephalopathy have been reported, especially in patients with prior treatment with cranial irradiation and antileukemic chemotherapy
  • Other:
  • -- Infusion reactions have been reported and may be indistinguishable from manifestations of cytokine release syndrome (CRS)
  • -- Tumor lysis syndrome has occurred; pretreatment, hydration, and monitoring are recommended; interruption or discontinuation may be necessary

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Gastrointestinal:Constipation (20%), Nausea (25%)
  • Hematologic:Anemia, All grades (18%), Anemia, Grade 3 or higher (13%), Febrile neutropenia, All grades (25%), Leukopenia, All grades (9%), Leukopenia, Grade 3 or higher (8%), Neutropenia, All grades (16%), Thrombocytopenia, All grades (11%), Thrombocytopenia, Grade 3 or higher (8%)
  • Other:Fever (62%)
Serious
  • Hematologic:Febrile neutropenia, Grade 3 or higher (23%), Neutropenia, Grade 3 or higher (15%)
  • Immunologic:Cytokine release syndrome (11%), Hypersensitivity reaction (1%)
  • Neurologic:Encephalopathy (5%), Encephalopathy, Leukoencephalopathy, Headache (36%), Neurotoxicity (50% (any grade); 15% (grade 3 or higher)), Tremor (20%)
  • Respiratory:Pneumonia (9%)
  • Other:Infectious disease, Serious (25%), Sepsis (7%), Tumor lysis syndrome (4%)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Blinatumomab is a bispecific CD19-directed CD3 T-cell engager that binds to CD19 (B-cells) and CD3 (T-cells). It connects CD3 in the T-cell receptor complex with CD19 on benign and malignant B cells to activate endogenous T cells. Blinatumomab helps form a synapse between the T cell and the tumor cell, upregulate cell adhesion molecules, produce cytolytic proteins, release inflammatory cytokines, and the proliferation of T cells, which result in redirected lysis of CD19+ cells.

2.title: Metabolism
2.mono: Metabolites: Small peptides and amino acids

3.title: Excretion
3.mono:
• Renal excretion: negligible amounts, unchanged drug
  • Total body clearance: 2.92 L/hr

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Intravenous
  • Use a 250 mL prefilled NS IV bag of polyolefin, PVC non-di-ethylhexylphthalate (non-DEHP), or ethyl vinyl acetate (EVA) only.
  • Ensure that the 250 mL prefilled NS IV bag has a starting volume of 265 to 275 mL, and add or remove NS if necessary to attain this desired volume.
  • For 9 mcg/day preparations, aseptically transfer 5.5 mL of IV solution stabilizer to the NS IV bag. For 28 mcg/day preparations, aseptically transfer 5.6 mL of IV solution stabilizer to the NS IV bag. Mix gently to avoid foaming. IV solution stabilizer is not for reconstitution of blinatumomab vials.
  • Reconstitute 1 vial of blinatumomab with 3 mL of preservative-free sterile water for injection (SWFI) for a final concentration of 12.5 mcg/mL; reconstitute 2 vials for preparation of 28 mcg/day over 48 hours. Direct SWFI toward the side of the vial, and gently swirl contents to minimize foaming; do not shake.
  • The reconstituted solution should be clear to slightly opalescent and colorless to slightly yellow. Do not use if the solution is cloudy or has precipitates.
  • The reconstituted solution may be protected from light and stored at room temperature (23 to 27 degrees C [73 to 81 degrees F]) for 4 hours or refrigerated at 2 to 8 degrees C (36 to 46 degrees F) for 24 hours.
  • For blinatumomab 9 mcg/day infused over 24 hours at a rate of 10 mL/hr, aseptically transfer 0.83 mL of reconstituted blinatumomab solution into the NS IV bag.
  • For blinatumomab 9 mcg/day infused over 48 hours at a rate of 5 mL/hr, aseptically transfer 1.7 mL of reconstituted blinatumomab solution into the NS IV bag.
  • For blinatumomab 28 mcg/day infused over 24 hours at a rate of 10 mL/hr, aseptically transfer 2.6 mL of reconstituted blinatumomab solution into the NS IV bag.
  • For blinatumomab 28 mcg/day infused over 48 hours at a rate of 5 mL/hr, aseptically transfer 5.2 mL of reconstituted blinatumomab solution into the NS IV bag (2.7 mL from 1 vial and 2.5 mL from the second vial).
  • Mix the IV bag gently to avoid foaming.
  • The prepared IV bag may be stored (including infusion time) for 48 hours at room temperature (23 to 27 degrees C [73 to 81 degrees F]) or refrigerated at 2 to 8 degrees C (36 to 46 degrees F) for 8 days.
  • Infuse through a dedicated line as a continuous IV infusion at a constant infusion rate using an infusion pump. Use pump cassettes and tubing of polyolefin, PVC non-di-ethylhexylphthalate (non-DEHP), or ethyl vinyl acetate (EVA) only. Ensure that the tubing is compatible with the infusion pump.
  • Aseptically attach the IV tubing to the IV bag with a sterile, nonpyrogenic, low protein-binding 0.2 micron in-line filter.
  • Remove air from IV bag, especially if using an ambulatory infusion pump.
  • Prime the IV line only with the infusion solution; do not prime the IV line with NS.
  • Do not flush the infusion line, especially when changing infusion bags, as it can cause excess dosage and complications.
  • Infuse at a rate of 10 mL/hr for 24-hour infusions or 5 mL/hr for 48-hour infusions.

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• complete remission or complete remission with partial hematological recovery indicates efficacy
  • signs and symptoms of cytokine release syndrome, including associated conditions of DIC, capillary leak syndrome, and hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis/macrophage activation syndrome
  • signs and symptoms of infusion reaction, which may be clinically indistinguishable from cytokine release syndrome
  • signs and symptoms of infection
  • signs and symptoms of tumor lysis syndrome
  • laboratory parameters, including WBC and absolute neutrophil count; during infusion
  • ALT, AST, gamma-glutamyl transferase, and total blood bilirubin; before and during treatment
  • signs and symptoms of neurotoxicity

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Advise patient to avoid activities requiring mental alertness or coordination until drug effects are realized due to potential for confusion, and coordination and balance disorders.
  • Counsel patient to report symptoms of cytokine release syndrome or an infusion reaction.
  • Instruct patient to report symptoms of neurologic toxicity (ie, convulsion, speech disorders, confusion).
  • Side effects may include pyrexia, headache, peripheral edema, nausea, hypokalemia, tremor, rash, constipation, or diarrhea.
  • Tell patient to report symptoms of an infection.
  • Warn patient that infusion pump settings should not be changed as this may result in dosing errors.
